characters: INT. CONFERENCE ROOM RSR CAPITAL DAY
INT/EXT. A WAREHOUSE CLUB, RED HOOK DOCKS, BROOKLYN
INT. DINER, UPSTATE NEW YORK MORNING

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DAVID NORRIS, 33, is having a private moment, looking dow thinking. He wears a suit and tie. He seems relaxed and confident. Content. Completely in his element. In one of his hands he's absentmindedly twirling a couple individually-wrapped Ricola throat lozenges. We hear the muffled voice of someone on a PA system outside:

dialogues.speaker: VOICE ON PA SYSTEM
dialogues.text: Thank you so much for coming today-- A man in a BLUE BLAZER walks up to David.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Congressman Norris-? Now REVEAL that we're Г‚В±fl: the entry hall of the Admin at St. Johns University. A thousand people crowd the quad out front. "Norris for Senate" placards everywhere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fred O'Malley with the DNC. I've never seen a crowd this big turn out so early in the cycle. CHARLIE TRAYNOR, 36, arrives--.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just wait 'till you see how they respond to him.. David pops a cherry lozenge into his mouth and straighten his lapel pin, which is shaped like New York State.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't build me up like that, Charlie. He'll be disappointed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The crowd, many of them in their twenties, roars with approval as David walks out to the lectern on the steps o the Admin Building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi there. I'm David Norris. And I'm running for the US Senate.
The crowd goes wild.

dialogues.speaker: SENATE CAMPAIGN
dialogues.text: --David finishes a speech at the FDNY Academy's graduatio The cadets jump to their feet and give him a standing ovation. --David shakes the hands of workers entering a .Con Ediso plant in Buffalo. He's a natural at this. Unlike most politicians he actually seems to enjoy campaigning. --Flashbulbs go off as he plays a game of pick-up basketb with a group of Bronx teenagers. Charlie is nearby. --David takes a ceremonial shovel full of dirt to begin redevelopment of an old military base upstate. --He gives a speech at a Harlem church. Audiences watch David the way they watched JFK, the way they watch Obama today. He inspires, makes them believe, makes them want t follow him. Especially young people. --David walks through a suburban mall happily shaking han as cameras follow him and citizens snap pictures with the camera-phones. People crush around him. He:doesn't seem t mind at all. He welcomes it. He feeds off it. --He pops a cherry lozenge in his mouth and climbs up ont tractor to speak to a gathering of upstate farmers, speak into a bullhorn to compensate for his hoarse voice. Charl stands nearby watching him speak:.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David enters his hotel room. The silence contrasts starkl with the noisy energy of the campaign trail. He turns on the TV. Scrolls through the channels. After a moment shuts it off. Total silence again. It bothers him. He opens up his briefcase. Pulls out a thick file -- his itinerary for the next three days. Dozens of speeches and meetings across the state. He glances at the summary page on the top. Glances down t page with his finger, stopping, almost at random, on a sp he's giving two days from now at the Westchester County O Space Initiative.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Karen Woods, founder. Husband: Bob.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kids: Samantha, painting, and Ricky, Little League. John Pascal. Wife: Anna. St. John's grad. Two year old: Loyita... He stops. Knows this cold. His finger runs down to a Realtor's Association breakfast in Nassau County four day out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Abagail "Abby" Best, Stuart Broxterman, Chapel Davis, Milan Sabovic, Jim Vargas... His ability to retain this sort of information is stunnin He doesn't need to review. It's already all there. He closes his itinerary file. Goes to the window and look out at the trees. The silence back...it's deafening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie enters the lobby. Stops suddenly: spots David, holding court at`the hotel bar. Fifteen strangers around as he regales them with a story, despite the fact that he clearly losing his voice. Charlie walks over, pulls him aside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell? What happened to "I'm going to have softie tea, rest my voice, and go to bed early?" You have Diane Sawyer tomorrow and you have to be up at four AM for us to make it in time. David is holding ,a beer, in his left hand. With his free he picks up a cup and saucer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I had some tea. (sees Charlie's not in the

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, man. We're eight points up in the polls. I've gotta cut loose every once in a while and have a life. This provokes a quizzical look from Charlie. Fifteen strangers in a crappy upstate Sheraton doesn't seem like having a life to him...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ten.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Latest poll has you ten points up. A slow smile spreads across David's face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sound of a busy room. Then one voice, much louder: CAMPAIGN AIDE. County reporting: 8901 for Lynfield, 7233 for Norris.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie Traynor walks over to the aide who just shouted t She's writing vote totals onto a map of New York by count

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Better than I thought, I thought we'd get killed in Seneca. He turns to look at a large suite full of more than a doz Norris supporters talking on phones and typing into lapto

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie, call Boyd! Where the hell are the. Suffolk numbers? We've got to get the Suffolk numbers!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A light snow falls. Four MEN IN CONSERVATIVE SUITS, overcoats, and fedoras walk across the roof of a forty-st building. Their clothing is more timeless than old- fashioned. And somehow so is their demeanor. The men get to the edge and look down over the city, almo as if it's their domain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David watches the election coverage on TV. Pundits are discussing the New York Senate race, which CNN has alread called for David's opponent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Congressman Norris has a reputation for being very direct, even blunt, in his campaign speeches, which is great until you say too many things you wish you hadn't. Then you start to look like an amateur.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's bad for any candidate but it's fatal if you're running for Senate at the age of 33, your opponent keeps calling you an "impulsive kid," and you almost killed your entire political career five months ago with an act of immaturity that ended up on the front page of`.the New York Post. David winces slightly. This is excruciating. Just then Charlie enters.. The nerve center.suite is visible throug the open door behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why are you still watching CNN? They called this way too early. David doesn't share his friend's optimism.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A' campaign aide with a phone to her ear shouts to the ro

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suffolk County Numbers! Charlie and David emerge from the private room to listen.

dialogues.speaker: AIDE, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: Lynfield: 415,120. Norris: 370,233. Charlie's energy and optimism disappear instantly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after long beat) I really thought we'd win Suffolk.
A senior aide walks over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kings County just came in too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He shows a piece of paper to Charlie and David. beat...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, it's over. And it's going to be a blowout... David puts on a brave face. . .but this is the first mome that he realizes not only is he going to lose, but he's g to lose big. It's going to be a grand,. public humiliatio

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NBC has us up next. Charlie takes a clicker and turns the closest TV to NBC.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Turning now to the New York Senate race, NBC is now calling the election for Roger'Lynfield. After a shockingly poor showing in both Suffolk county and in his home county, Kings, it now appears that David Norris will lose this election badly, perhaps by as much as 10 points.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The four men in dark suits.. The boss's name is RICHARDSO early 40s. His top aide is.AHARRY, 50s.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is a.bignight, gentleman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is ever ything set? Harry nods. Richardson notices his eyes:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You look tired. You should take a vacation when we finish with this. You'll have earned it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not sure the kind of tired I feel would be fixed by a vacation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure it would. Everybody needs a vacation. Even us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The staff and supporters in here have become very quiet. Their candidate is standing in the middle of the room, bu one can look at him. And David can't look at them either.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to take a walk, figure out my speech.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Four-hundred campaign workers follow election news on big screens in the Waldorf's Grand Ballroom. No one says a wo The mood has gone from.hopeful to funereal in sixty secon

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David slips through the lobby with only a few looks from staff. But when he.gets to the door he sees that press va line the front of the hotel. There will be no peace for h if he steps out there. He turns around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good evening, Congressman. You're in the Grand Ballroom if that's what you're looking for.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Actually just looking for a place to be alone for a minute before I head in there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: None of the banquet rooms on the third floor are in use tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David stands alone looking out at the empty room. Trying get used to it. It's not easy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David enters the huge, ornate, men's room and goes to the of sinks. He pulls two Ricola cherry lozenges from his pocket. He twirls them in his hands for a moment. Then tosses them into the trash can. He looks at himself the mirror, fighting to hold himself together. A sound behind him. David spins to see a WOMAN exiting on of the stalls. She's in a stunning ball gown and carrying expensive bottle of champagne.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi. I hope I didn't startle you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing in here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hiding from security.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh... . What did you do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crashed a wedding. One floor up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's almost midnight. They'just caught on now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ivana Trump finally realized I wasn't her niece. I think after the fifth; glass of champagne my Czech accent started slipping. spite of David's state that gets a grin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you for real?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Life is short.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hard to argue with that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're that guy running for Senate aren't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm "that guy."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You winning?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Too bad. The other guy's a tool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe I should have made that clearer in my ads.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Personally, I think mooning your friends at a college reunion is no big deal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I don't think the Post should have printed the photo. David just shakes his head. He will never, ever live that down and he knows it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At least not full page. He can't help but crack up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, I've done it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You weren't running, for Senate at the time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you still have a chance or is it over?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He crushed me. She has beautiful eyes. And an exceptional gift for conveying empathy...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must ...I don't know what you must be feeling...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Winning would feel better. But losing has its advantages.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The only time a politician is alone is when he's asleep.. .or in the bathroom. After eight years in politics that gets kind of hard to take. She tilts her head a little, gives him a curious look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Watching you, you'd never know it. The way she looks at him, the way she says it, David know she sees what others miss in him -- even if he isn't even quite sure what it is. Not yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, everything happens for a reason, right? Even losing. God, I'm really rollrng out the platitudes tonight, aren't I?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the champagne. Brines out the Hallmark in people.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After it kills their Czech accents. She offers:him the bottle. He hesitates, then takes it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not? I have to think up some good platitudes for my speech. He takes a gulp of champagne.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why the hell would you do that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Apparently, even if I hadn't been caught dropping my drawers in the middle of a senate campaign I would have lost the election anyway because I'm too blunt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (swig of champagne) Says who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The TV pundits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck 'em. They just wish they had the balls to be candidates themselves. She hands him the champagne bottle again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And they work for the Man anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You going to run again?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tonight's probably not the night to ask.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, it is. Look at me. You have to run again. Do-yo hear me? She's serious about this. Intense.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Otherwise the-country will be run by tools. like Lynwood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Field." (of f her look) "Lynfield." A beat. She shrugs. Then they lean toward each other... and kiss. It turns mo and more passionate. When they finally pull apart:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holy shit. She seems just as surprised. They look at each other and laugh. Just then the bathroom door opens. It's Charlie. He sees David and the woman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I better go.
She exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The woman comes out of the bathroom. David is right behin her. Then Charlie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait. The woman turns to face David. Suddenly two hotel guards turn the corner and spot the woman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There! They rush toward her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gotta go. (to David, emphatically.) Don't let the bastards grind you down. She spins and sprints away. The hotel guards chase her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell was that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm really not sure. David has a huge grin on his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I think I'm ready to give my speech.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David as he walks out from behind a curtain onto the dais His supporters start clapping... . but clearly they're heartbroken. David looks completely peaceful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I grew up in Red Hook and I don't want to shock anybody but I got in a few fist fights along the way. Laughter ripples through the crowd. We don't know enough to get the joke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And we used to have a saying when you got in a fight: "it's not whether or not you get knocked down -- because eventually everyone does -- it's what you do when you get back up."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry, I'm not going to moon you. The audience explodes with laughter this time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I am... (waiting for the laughter to die down) But I am going to get backup. I wanted to come out here tonight and give you a victory speech, a speech I've dreamed of giving foremost of my life. But life doesn't always deal you the cards you want. The audience sobered now. Reflective.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My life changed when I was ten years old. My entire world turned upside-down.' His audience,. knows exactly what he's talking about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And as I looked for something to -hang ;on to, something; to help me cope' with what had. happened the only thing that made sense to me was service. Finding a way to do something with my life that left this world a little better than I found it. The audience is moved. Tears begin to well up. People dab at their eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sky is just beginning to turn from black to deep blue The park is still and silent. A black Mercedes pulls up on Madison Ave. Mr. Richardson, again in a dark suit, gets out and enters the park.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harry sits on one of the benches -- a fedora in his lap t complement a gray flannel suit. Richardson arrives.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He spills his coffee when he steps out of Starbucks. The moment he comes through the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our models indicate between 7:00 and 7:05 am. Harry nods but he seems distant Richardson sees this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You planned that vacation, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two weeks. Richardson claps him din-the shoulder and leaves. Harry watches him go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An alarm clock reads "5:44 airy." It turns to "5:45" and alarm goes off. A hand reaches over and taps the alarm of FOLLOW the arm back to David Norris in a king-sized bed. rubs his eyes, stretches his neck, and climbs out of bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David works out. He's got the-energy-level of a 25 year-o He runs on a treadmill. Hits the heavy bag. Does sit-ups.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EXAMINE David's spacious one-bedroom overlooking Madison Square Park. His desk and dining room table is covered wi stacks of paper and files. A flat screen displays CNBC:

dialogues.speaker: CNBC ANCHOR, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: RSR Capital announced yesterday that David Norris would become its Vice Chairman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David shaves.

dialogues.speaker: CNBC ANCHOR, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Norris worked at Goldman Sachs for four years before running for Congress at the tender age of 25.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A desk is set up at one end of the living room. A new mod blackberry on the desk next to another cell phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He served four terms in the House-- The blackberry rings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --prior to his unsuccessful bid for Senate in last week's election. David rushes over and ?icks=up the blackberry. He has to look for a second to figure out how to hit "answer."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RSR, one ofthe country's fastest- growing hedge funds is run by NO ris's former Goldman colleague and campaign chairman, Charles

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The blackberry rings again. It's very loud.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: . his . electrifying concession speech led commentators to-- Finally David finds the answer button as he mutes the TV.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE, (TEL. V.0)
dialogues.text: Tom Frankel from the Journal is calling you in five minutes. I just gave him this number.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give him 3227. I'm not used to this phone yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't. He's going to ask you about joining the firm. My compliance guys say all firm business has to be done on the blackberry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sarbanes-Oxley. You voted for it, pal. In fact, you cosponsored it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Through the window we see David getting his morning coffe He exits and LEAVES FRAME. HOLD on the door of Starbucks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harry is snoring on his bench. David walks past.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David arrives at Fifth just in time to catch the "M1 Limi Stop" bus arriving`at the stop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sunlightpeeks:.through a gap in the buildings and falls o Harry's left eye, waking him. He bolts upright. Checks hi watch, Shit! He looks around quickly. Spots David about t get o n the bus. Harry leaps : up--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: .As David pays, he notices Harry sprinting for the bus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir, there's someone--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's another M1 right behind me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bus pulls out. Harry keeps running after it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As David walks down the aisle a couple of passengers recognize his face. . .but they don't say anything. David nears an empty aisle seat. A woman is curled up in window seat, sleeping. She wears a funky mini-dress, knee high argyle socks under leather boots, and a (clashing) argyle bucket cap. David sits next to her. And stares.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No way... It's the woman from election night.', He leans around to to see the front of her face. "It's definitely her. His eyes drift down at her legs. Just then she opens her eyes She recoils for a second;. Then` her eyes soften when she realizes who it is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think. we "ve met.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You need a better line than that or I'll have to assume you're a pervert who likes to stare at girls' legs while-, they sleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiles, game on) Your skirt was so short I couldn't help it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Skirt, dress, same thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you're a pervert, yeah. All that matters is they both show leg.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So do shorts, dear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, but there's that pesky piece of fabric right here that interferes with your fantasy life. She shuts her eyes and leans against the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wake me when you have a good come back to that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have one but, unlike you, I wouldn't say it in public.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (eyes still closed) Pussy. David laughs. Can not believe this woman. In a good way. His blackberry RINGS. Her eyes pop open. David.picks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello...? Hello? David looks at his. phone. The signal has gone to zero.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The line cut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That ringer get any-louder or do you pretty much have it maxed out?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're relentless.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never sleep through the night. I catch up on the bus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You going to run again?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just started a new job, today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I saw your concession speech. I heard Bill Clinton called it the best political speech he's seen in 20 years. David looks back at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something got into me. He means her. They stare at each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the deal with you and argyles?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the deal with you and boring shades of blue? David is wearing a Navy blue suit, blue shirt, and blue t A beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At least my clothes match.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's easy if you. restrict yourself to one color.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The belt and shoes are black.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Variety is the spice of .life .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There you` go with the platitudes again. I guess it wasn't the ch mpagne . His blackberry goes again. RING-RING.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello? Hello? He shakes his head. It's dead again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harry runs down Broadway looking east on 19th to try to s the bus on Park.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your phone sucks. Don't guys like you get special phones that actually work in the middle of the biggest city in the country?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Depends what the telecom lobby thinks of your voting record.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harry spots the bus passing on Park. He jams his fedora o his head and stretches his arm out--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David's phone rings again. As he reaches for the phone he fumbles his coffee cup, the lid comes off, and a slosh of coffee crests the brim and splashes on the woman's dress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Jesus...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harry's face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit! He's looking at a leather portfolio. We catch a glimpse inside: a complicated circuit diagram. Harry shuts the book, look's up to get a bead on" the the bus, then takes Broadway, again, hoping to cut it off at Union Square.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll pay for the damage. He pulls out his wallet. There's $7 inside. She laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hope your new job pays better than your old one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give me your number and I'll send you a check.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God, that is smooth. Spill coffee on me then ask for my number. She takes the coffee from his hands and casually takes a then turns back to him with a devilish look in her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just let me spill some on you and we'll be even. She thrusts the cup toward his tie. David parries.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's my first day at the office!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell your boss some crazy chick dumped coffee on you on the MI. It's New York; he'll understand. She thrusts the cup back at him-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No! He grabs the cup with both his hands over hers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on. Just a little. They struggle with the cup. <,;:Both suppressing laugh

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're crazy. Actually crazy. The phone on David's lap'RINGS again. She snatches it wit her free hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's not here! She hangs up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who was that? She shrugs. Sorry, pal. He lunges for his phone, but she holds it on the other side of her body.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is this, third grade?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You forgot what that was like, didn't you? How fun it was... That stops him for a moment. Until the phone RINGS again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my God! How do you stand it? She drops the phone into the coffee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There. We're even. He stares at her. Incredulous. They lock eyes. God knows what would come next if they were in private... The fourth RING gurgles up through the coffee. A beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sturdy little fucker, isn't it? She pulls the phone out of the cup and wipes it off with scarf, pushing the button which sends the call to voice m Then she reaches out her hand, as if to shake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By the way, I'm Elise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elise exits.. the bus. David stands at the bus door watch her. She turns back to look at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The morning after .I lost I woke up thinking about you . That melts her. Instantly. All her bravado drops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moments later. Through the window, David watches Elise walking down the sidewalk. Their eyes meet. She blows him a little kiss before she turns the corner. His heart skip a beat as the bus continues on down Union Square East.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harry runs through Union Square bee-lining for David's bu

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David looks at Elise's number, scribbled on a piece of pa He carefully tucks her number into his wallet. Then takes the most satisfying sip of coffee he's ever had in his li

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Spotting David through the bus window, Harry thrusts his Fedora back onto his head and points at the bus--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just as David finishes his sip the-plastic lid pops off t cup. A second earlier and the coffee would have poured al over his shirt. Instead it spills: on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dammit! Harry sprints out onto lark Avenue now, right behind the HONK! Harry turns just in time to see a.taxi skid into hi TRUNK! He rolls up onto the hood--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A big corner office. The phone rings. Charlie picks up.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID, (TEL. V.O.)
dialogues.text: Guess who I just sat down next to on the bus?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The woman from election night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A dazed Harry lies in the road... The taxi driver who hit him jumps out of his car to see if Harry is okay...

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE, (TEL. V.O.)
dialogues.text: The one you kissed?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She kissed me. I just didn't fight it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harry sits up... He's bruised but okay. He looks around f something. Spots his crushed hat under the taxi's front tire.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: You're shitting me. Just randomly you sit down next to-- He's cut off mid-word.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie? David looks at his phone. "Call Lost" on the screen. Davi hits redial. Gets a fast busy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ' (to himself). This is ridiculous. He pockets his phone.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. PARK AVENUE SOUTH MORNING
dialogues.text: The taxi driver is with Harry now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you okay? Harry is sitting now, wincing, but still searching intent for something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm fine-- Will you hand me that? Harry points at his leather portfolio on the pavement a f feet away. We'll come to know it as a "PLANBOOK."

dialogues.speaker: TAXI DRIVER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Are you sure you're okay? The driver hands it to him. Harry flips to a bookmarked page and we get our first good look at that circuit diagr Thousands of interconnected lines. Dozens of geometric symbols at intersection points. And written notations in language as complex as Sanskrit crossed with Chinese. And, maybe it's just a trick of the light but several of lines appear to re-arrange themselves on the page.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh...shit...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David's still grinning as he reaches his downtown office tower. He enters through the revolving door--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Empty, except for a bored-looking security guard at the o end of the lobby. David gets into an empty elevator.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David walks past the receptionist She's on the phone. He waves as-he:passes by. No wade back. She must not see him

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay... Daviddecides he doesn't need to announce himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David enters to find the office suite quiet... Not a soul in sight. Not a single secretary is here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (loud, playful) Doesn't anybody bother getting in before eight at this place? David passes a couple of empty offices on his way towards large corner suite where a secretary sits outside an offi marked "Charles Traynor, Chairman." She's smiling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Susan! How are you today? (when she doesn't move) Susan? David looks closer across her desk. Her face is frozen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Susan? He leans across her desk, touches her arm. She stays dead still. David rushes through Charlie's door:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Call 911! Something's wrong with Susan!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --and rushes in to find that Charlie is frozen too -- wit the phone up to his ear. Like he's in a wax museum. He is surrounded by four men in bulky, metallic silver protective suits .(think airport firefighter gear). One of the men adjusts three metal. probes which are atta to the left side.of Charlie's skull.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus! Three men in business suits talking by the window spin to David. it's Mr. Richardson and-two aides we recognize as "security guards" who chased Elise away on election night

dialogues.speaker: DAVID, (,.CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What the hell are you doing?! Richardson blinks Clearly surprised. Then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grab him! David bolts out of the office as they lunge at him--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David sprints toward the door he came in. It closes as he gets there. He grabs it. It's locked. He sprints away into an internal hallway. Richardson emer from a door in the middle of the hallway.
David jumps a mile. It's physically impossible that Richardson could have gotten there that fast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't get away, David. David spins and rushes back into the main office, then do an internal staircase to the floor below. Jumps the last five steps and hits the floor hard. As he comes up he runs smack into another RSR employee wh frozen solid. David curses, then dives around the frozen employee to fi Richardson, coming out of another office. down the hall. Again, physically impossible for him to get there that fa David spins and-- A DISTORTED WIDE ANGLE SHOT of a chloroform rag shoved right at us. FOCUS GOES IN AND OUT. FROM DAVID'S POV, BLURRY FOCUS as he's carried toward one the large corner offices on the 40th floor. The nameplate reads "Steve Kincaid." Richardson opens the door and ushers his men, carrying Da

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Except when they walk through the door they're not in an office 40 floors above lower Manhattan,: they step inside large warehouse... Their movement completely violates the laws of physics.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence. Then voices come up slowly:

dialogues.speaker: RICHARDSON, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. No, sir. No, sir. I understand that, sir. Absolutely. I'll do that, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What a goddamm mess.

dialogues.speaker: MCCRADY, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: Was that Donaldson?

dialogues.speaker: RICHARDSON, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: MCCRADY, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: What do you want to do?

FADE UP -- BLURRY AT FIRST -- to DAVID'S POV of the wareh David caught a glimpse of just before he passed out. A half-dozen members of the "Intervention Team" (the Silv Suits) stand nearby. Richardson and MCCRADY (one of the m from the rooftops) stand behind David, about 20 feet away

dialogues.speaker: RICHARDSON, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: Can you reset him?

dialogues.speaker: MCCRADY, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: I don't think we have the authority in a situation like this.

dialogues.speaker: BURDENSKY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Legal just arrived.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: REVEAL BURDENSKY, a 50 year-old in a pin-stripe suit, carrying a briefcase. He.walks to Richardson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Re-setting's off the table. This is our fault:... Richardson glances irately at Harry, who stands by himsel off to the side, clearly disgraced. David, who is tied to a chair facing away from Richardson cranes around to see who's talking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey. The suits stare back in silence for a beat, then turn bac talking amongst themselves -- though at a lower volume.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are my options?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You could bullshit him but you'll never be completely successful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can somebody tell me what's going on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (still ignoring him) The questions will burn in him till the day he dies. You'll have to monitor him constantly...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He can hear little snippets of what Burdensky's saying--

dialogues.speaker: BURDENSKY, (PARTIALLY AUDIBLE)
dialogues.text: .to make sure he doesn't talk... the endless ripple effects... REVEAL David untying the rope restraining him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If it were me, I'd level with him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Completely?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the only way to extinguish his curiosity. Richardson turns and studies David. Then walks over to hi An uncomfortable pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who are you guys?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're the people v ho make sure things happen according to Plan. David stares back at him for a moment. then leaps up. His rope comes off and the chair falls. He sprints toward an open door forty feet across the warehou Richardson makes a little gesture with his hand--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It cracks.. .and displaces upward.. .so it's uneven just David's foot comes down on it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David trips and goes flying--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David is dragged back to the center of the room and place back in his chair in front of Richardson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you really think I couldn't see that coming? David dabs blood from his lip, which split during the fal

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can read your mind! David stares back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, really...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Choose a color. (barely a beat) Blue. Choose a number. (even less time) Seventeen. David's jaw drops slightly. Richardson was clearly right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now,. why are you still deciding whether or not to run? David's hands go to his head`, involuntarily, an atavisti response, as if;s.omehow that will keep his thoughts from spilling out into view.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You saw the futility of that back at the office. David's entire reality has finally been bent to the break point. He can't hang on any longer to an explanation for this based in the world he's known to date...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell is happening to me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You just saw behind a curtain you weren't even supposed to know was there, Mr. Norris. Its jarring. I'm sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just... came to work...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It wasn't your fault. Your Path through the world this morning was supposed to be adjusted. (glancing bitterly at Harry, in the corner) Your coffee was supposed to.spill onto your shirt as you left Starbucks near your apartment. You would have gone up to change and arrived at work ten minutes later than you did. By then we would have left.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: People call it "chance" when their coffee spills or their internet goes down or they misplace their keys. Sometimes it is. Sometimes it's:us...nudging you back on Plan. David takes all this in. He's still shell-shocked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whatever you were doing to Charlie back there... it wasn't misplacing his keys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sometimes. when nudging a person back on Plan isn't enough we intervene directly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why Charlie? What did you do to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You need to worry about getting back on your Plan, David, not worry about us putting him back on his. David stares back, still trying to get his bearings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only a handful of human beings know what you now know, David. We're determined to keep it that way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So before I let you go, you need to understand something: If you ever reveal our existence we will erase your brain. Your memories, your emotions, your entire personality will be expunged. Your friends and family will think you've gone crazy. You won't "think" anything because a blank slate can't "think." Davidstares back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you understand what I just said?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not a word. Not one word about us. (long beat as he studies

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: okay ... . you're free to go. David stands there a monent..:.not sure it's real. Richar points at the door. David walks toward it. Just then another man comes up to Richardson.

dialogues.speaker: NEW MAN IN SUIT
dialogues.text: There's awoman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's always & Woman... Richardson motions;to his men. At.-THE DOOR Two men come through from outside and block David's exit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He said I could go.

dialogues.speaker: NEW MAN IN SUIT
dialogues.text: You won't believe who she is. He holds open a Planbook for Richardson to see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How is that possible? Why didn't we get an alert?

dialogues.speaker: NEW MAN IN SUIT
dialogues.text: He wasn't supposed to be on that bus. He was supposed to be changing his shirt in his apartment... It was a controlled situation. It was supposed to be. The new man looks at Harry.

dialogues.speaker: AT THE DOOR
dialogues.text: David looks back at Richardson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You said I could go. Richardson walks over to him.

dialogues.speaker: RIC,HARDSON
dialogues.text: You ran into a woman named Elise on the bus this morning?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (:going very still) Why does it'matter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You weren't ever supposed to see her again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why do you care.?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because, David, you can't be with her. And we didn't want to have to resort to this-- Four big guys grab David and pull his arms backwards like prison guards incapacitating a prisoner. Richardson reach into David's pocket and pulls out his wallet--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell-- What are you-- Richardson removes the piece of paper that Elise wrote he number on from David's wallet--
Richardson places the wallet back in David's pocket, then pulls out a lighter--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No! And burns Elise's number. David strains and tries to pull loose from the vice-like grip of the four Intervention Te men. But he can't get free.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is wrong with you people?! Richardson drops the paper on the floor and lets it burn. ON David's reaction CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David exits through a steel door., it clangs shut behind He stands there unable to proceed for a long beat then st walking to the corner to orient himself. Down one street he spots the Manhattan Bridge, down the o the Brooklyn Bridge. He's in DUMBO.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David sits alone at the bar. His hand trembles slightly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're David Norris, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ice water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's it? David nods. Harry arrives.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We should talk. But not here. Go back to work and I'll contact you later today with a place to meet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. Harry can see that David is still very shaken.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The world's exactly the same as it's always been. You just understand it more completely now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hang on to what mattered before you knew any of this and you'll be fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A thousand-yard stare on his face, David walks toward downtown Manhattan amid dozens of--pedestrian commuters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David enters. Stares at,,hisnew colleagues going about th business as if nothing happened.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David stands in ftontof the corner office labeled "Steve Kincaid." He hesitates, then opens it. He sees an empty office with a killer view of New-,York Harbor. It's stran disorienting for him.

dialogues.speaker: SECRETARY, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: Mr. IKincaid's in the finance meeting, Congressitan. Main conference room. David turns to see her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks. David walks away, still trying to get his bearings in the reality he now knows. Charlie comes around a corner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There you are. I called your cell ten times. You left me hanging.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (seeing the look in

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you okay? (off David's nod) Come on, we're late. Happy first day by the way. They head towards the conference room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You sure you're okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine. How about you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great. Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No headaches or--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I feel fantastic, -man. Is it just, me or is this an odd conversation? (off David" s non-response.) What the hell happened with the girl?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After the meeting.

dialogues.speaker: INT. CONFERENCE ROOM RSR CAPITAL DAY
dialogues.text: LONG SHOT from outside the building. The firm's partners at their weekly investment committee meeting. David watch Charlie intently, looking for what's changed...

dialogues.speaker: INT RSR CAPITAL OFFICES
dialogues.text: David and Charlie walk back to David's office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please explain to me why you don't have an ear-to-ear smile right now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David hesitates. It's like his friend is an alien.. .but again he's totally normal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I lost her number.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You lost her number?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (searching for something) I was pickpocketed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on. You can't be serious. (off David's look) You're serious... Oh, man...dude. I'm sorry... I'm really sorry...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David sits on a bench looking at the water. The wind pick up and he puts his hands in his,coatpockets to keep them warm. His right hand feels something. He pulls out a ticket for the 4 pm Circle..Line tourist boat cruise. EXT. CIRCLE LINE CRUtgE -- DAY The boat pulls away front=the dock. It's misting rain so there's only asmattering of tourists on-board. David stan looking back at Manhattan. Harry is next to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A lot of people just collapse when they see what you've s'een. Their personal choices suddenly seem meaningless to them. Life starts to feel pointless.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was` raised to believe there's something behind the curtain. I just never pictured it quite like this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Most people don't. Harry looks over his shoulder, scans for any signs of his colleagues. He's far from relaxed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How are you feeling?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You should know. You can read my mind, right?
Harry hesitates...as if he's not sure how much to tell Da how far to go with this. Finally:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richardson was just trying to scare you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He knew what color I was thinking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because he set it up as a choice. "Choose a color. Choose a number"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So? Harry looks away. He's crossing a line. He's really putti himself out there:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can't read your mind or hear your thoughts. But before you make a choice your brain weighs options, and we percpite that. We know if you're going to go off Plan "or not because, as long as we're close enough, we cansense it when it's about to happen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: it-;' s like a sixth sense for you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seventh, actually.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did they do too Charlie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Made some small change in the way he assesses risk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What type of risk?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (this is beside the point) I don't know. Something arcane. Something to do with mortgage- backed securities.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's all?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What would your colleagues do to you if they knew what you were telling me? This is precisely what Harry has been worried about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's why we're meeting out here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're not following me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We don't have the manpower to follow everybody all the time. They're checking in on you. Just not here. Not right now. ON David's face considering this.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. UPPER DECK DAY
dialogues.text: Moments later. They stand out of earshot of the few tourists up here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why are you helping me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have my reasons. David studies him. Ha=rry's' clearly not ready to go into

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why do they care if I'm with Elise?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your entire reality gets shattered this morning and you want to know about a woman?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why do they care? Harry looks back at him. Taken aback a bit by how much Da seems to care.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have no idea?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All I know is, given the amount of resources they've used, keeping you from her is pretty important to them. (off David's silence) You're going to look for her aren't you? Again, David is silent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are twelve million people in this city. On a slow day. You're not going to find her, you do realize that, don't yore-?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Even if a hypnotist pulled her number out of the recesses of your brain, no matter how many times you called it, you,'d never get through...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (his face hardening) They send you here to tell me that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want my advice? Forget about her. Accept that you'`>ll never see her again. Move on with your life. ON David as Harry's words sink in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huge shafts of morning sunlight cut across the park outsi David's apartment. The trees are blooming. It's Spring no

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An alarm clock reads 6:29 am. David lies alone in bed. He already awake, staring at the ceiling... After a long beat the alarm clock rings. David shuts it off. But then just lies there...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the same apartment -- except it's bigger now. Instea of two large windows on the park, his apartment is now si windows across. (He has bought the two one-bedrooms next his and knocked the walls down). Three years have passed. No files on the table, like there were the last time we w here. David is on the phone in a new park-view study.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE, (PHONE V.O.)
dialogues.text: How are you feeling about the speech? David has not noticeably aged and yet he's more tempered subdued than when we last saw him. We `hear it in his voi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm ready... I changed a few things last night.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE, (PHONE V.O.)
dialogues.text: Tell me at breakfast.

dialogues.speaker: THROUGH THE WINDOW AT DAVID
dialogues.text: David finishes his call, then looks out the window. There a detachment in h-s eyes that didn't exist before. After moment, he gets his=coat and heads for the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David exits Starbucks with a coffee. He walks across the park toward the same Fifth Avenue bus stop he did three y ado.` Even his posture and,-gait are different.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David enters the Ml bus. He feeds his Metrocard into the reader as he looks down the aisle scanning the riders.. . out of habit than actual hope. He walks back to take a se

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David stares idly out the window. His Blackberry buzzes w a text message. Looks down at it. Then looks back out the window. Suddenly his eyes snap into focus. DAVID'S POV: The bus passes a woman walking on the sidewa

David's head whips around, only able to see her from the now. She walks like Elise. She's dressed in the same eclectic style. He slams the red "next stop" strip, jumps to his feet, and runs to the front of the bus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop the bus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The next stop--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bus stops. David jumps out on Broadway. FOLLOW him as he takes off across the street and runs down 12th. He catches up to her at University Place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elise! The woman turns around. And it's her...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wow... How areyou. Reeling from the adrenaline; David takes a moment, then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (from the heart) I rode the Ml to work every day for the last three years hoping one day I'd run into you again. She's amused, rather than moved, because she doesn't buy

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Calling would have been easier.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I couldn't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Girlfriend wouldn't let you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No girlfriend. She looks at him with continued skepticism. But his expression is dead serious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can we go somewhere and talk? She hesitates. It hurt when he didn't call. She's angry a herself for that, but it's the truth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (re: his suit) Don't you have to get to work?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just got sick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "I haven't seen you in three years - - You make me sick" is not an ideal come-on. For the record. David smiles. She's softening. A little. His phone vibrates. He pulls it out of his pocket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One second.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CharlieT can't make breakfast.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE, (PHONE V.O.)
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And...I might have to push the speech.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE, (PHONE V.O.)
dialogues.text: What? Are you crazy?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just ran into Elise. He hangs up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You just hung up on your best friend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've known each other since we were kids. We have a shorthand.
He's not being flip or clever or smooth. He's being matte of-fact. Serious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What speech?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doesn't matter. Let's take a walk. His focus on her is absolute. But she's wary of getting reeled in again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somewhere far. We have a lot to talk about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think you should cancel your speech. What if I don't like you at the end of our walk?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll take my chances.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seri6us1y, my number hasn't changed:. Just call me like you didn't last time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My-speech will always be there, you might not be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was there, David. You didn't callrie!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walk with me and I'll explain that. She's still dubious. His phone vibrates. This time he tur it off .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a statement of fact) I'm not losing you again. I'm not letting you out of my sight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stalker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can we walk? The moment she finally relents, CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Polished black shoes running down a corridor on an imposs shiny black floor with inlaid decorative silver borders.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Richardson sits at a large desk. The design is Art De crossed with Albert Speer. Downtown Manhattan is visible the 30th floor window. Richardson's aide enters.

dialogues.text: We have a problem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David and Elise walk north.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's been years, David. How do you know I don't have a boyfriend? Oh, shit. He hasn't even had time to think about that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: you have a boyfriend?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would it-Matter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh...yeah...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So all the stuff about me being in your mind constantly for the last three years was just talk... The truth is you don't have any real conviction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It wouldn't matter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you don't care about being a home-wrecker?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay... if you were married it would matter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now you're just trying to say what you think I want to hear. A beat. She lets David twist in the wind...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.text: Now let's hear your bullshit excuse for never calling me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't have your number.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was taken from me. I was mugged.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, come on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your number was in my Wallet and they ,:took it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm serious. What else could possibly-explain my fawning all over you on that bus three years ago...and again today and not calling you in between?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Um, you had a girlfriend and you felt guilty. I have a thing about being lied to, David.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I swear to God I didn't have your number. I swear on my parents' graves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And none of them were you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after a beat) You really are smooth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not fair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's okay. I like it. I probably shouldn't, but I do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's Sellas. Elise Sellas.

dialogues.text: McCrady holds open his Planbook to show Richardson an eve shifting diagram.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me you're kidding. How could our Path-analysis miss this? McCrady just shakes his head, mystified... Richardson wal to the closet and pulls out his fedora:.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'rlhek,e are they now?`

dialogues.text: Central Park. Bethesda Fountain.

dialogues.text: According to Maxim, I'm supposed to "maintain eye contact and ask you what you do for a living." It's the first witty comment h6' :s made this time around He's just barely starting t6Г‚В°'looГ‚В§`en up.

dialogues.text: Oh..

dialogues.text: I think you have the wrong idea about me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

He points at the Boathouse restaurant a few hundred feet the path they're on.

dialogues.text: Yeah...

dialogues.text: We could wait an hour and call it lunch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So unfair...

dialogues.text: Richardson and McCrady Step out of a small outdoor bar structure. They, SpotDavid and Elise walking in the side door of the restaurant.',., Somehow Richardson and' McCrady have travelled from downt Manhattan to the middle of Central Park in the time it to David and Elise to' walk 100 feet...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.text: How do you do that? I can't remember the names of people I just met.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (points at himself) David.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right.. Thanks_.'

dialogues.text: 36 hours without contact and she'll never speak to him again. I've studied her file. Her deepest fear in life is--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, something is wrong. I'm already seeing inflection points. Off Richardson's surprised look--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Davidand Elise eat brunch.

dialogues.text: Ballet is basically impossible to do correctly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You just do absurd things. with your body. The movement is completely unnatural. It requires incredible strength in all sorts of random muscles. And you have to be born with ridiculous amounts of flexibility in your hip or you'll never be an y good.

dialogues.text: McCrady examines his Planbook diagram. With each new upda of the diagram red "inflection points" move across the pa toward a heavy black "present time" line on the right sid the right :page Richardson points at the red point closest to the present tithe ` hrie .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If they kiss...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A kiss, that's all it takes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A real kiss. But once they do that every possible adjustment that's strong enough to break them up will cause ripples over your limit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If Melton and Morris do their jobs right we'll be okay. But Richardson is clearly worried.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David and Elise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the history of ballet there've only been a handful of people who actually did ballet the way it's supposed to be done. Forme that just made it completely addictive.

dialogues.text: Do you ever get nervous when people watch you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not really. Do you get anxious when you make 'a speech?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I get more anxious alone in my apartment than in front of an auditorium full of people. Everything's backwards for me. VOICE (OS. I hate to interrupt. They turn to see Charlie'''aynor. I tXT. BOATHOUSE PATIO DAY Richardson turns to a colleague, Melton, who steps throug the "bar house" door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.text: God, don't skip this for me.

dialogues.text: I told you I'm not letting you out of my sight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David, what the hell?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.text: Where does your company perform?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're n in our space. There was a`;ГўВЂВўpower ot outage or something. (checking the text) We're using a space" on Murray and West Broadway today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But we've got to leave right now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (putting his hat on) We're not out of the woods yet. He looks down at the inflection points in McCrady's Planb

dialogues.text: David and Charlie and Elise walk:toward the side. entranc

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. David and Elise stop to say goodbye to-each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.text: Richardson makes a small hand motion in Charlie's directi

dialogues.text: David leans toward Elise--

Turning so the sun is out of,=hereyes causes the daughter notice the TV: an image of David's famous concession spee from three years ago. A screen graphic reads "Announcing Today?" As the daughter turns back to look at her mother, she not David, over her mom's shoulder...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: just want to

dialogues.text: I hope the rumors are true, Congressman. David pulls back fr`bm Elise, suddenly self-conscious, tu to see the 40-year old woman Richardson just manipulated. She points at the TV report on David's announcement.

dialogues.text: Thanks. Thanks a lot. David turns back to Elise.

dialogues.text: On the phone.

dialogues.text: I'm wrangling him right now--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whatever happens...I'm not going to let anything stand between us this time. It's such an odd thing to say, if you don't know what Dav has gone through. She gives him a quizzical look. But she's also moved by his,tone

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.:.. I believe you. Of course I tend to believe in the wrong people. Especially men. It's the kind of quip that's more truth than jest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not this time. He leans in to kiss her--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A horrified look from Richardson--

dialogues.text: David kisses Elise on the cheek. But he lingers... Then pulls. away without going further...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll see you in two hours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richardson and his colleagues all breathe a large sigh of relief.. .as they watch David leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're okay...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was way too close. What the hell is going on with this case?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David and Charlie ride in the back. Charlie looks at Davi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've just never seen you like that. David can't possibly explain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "I'm going to-postpone my announcement to have brunch with a woman?" Postpone any speech. I know she made an impression on you but this is ... Charlie just shakes his head, unable to comprehend. A bea

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richardson. Yes, sir. Believe me, it was a surprise to me too. But I think we have it under control.

dialogues.text: Elise and her friend, LAUREN, 20s, stretch between routin An unexpected smile spreads across Elise's face.

dialogues.text: Oh, you're clone. You're gone...

dialogues.text: .I'm here today to honor that, and to announce my intention to run for the United States Senate...

dialogues.text: Don't worry. That's definite.

dialogues.text: The audience applauds energetically. David nods "thank yo and steps away from the lectern they set up. He shakes tw or three people's hands but then heads inside the buildin

dialogues.text: Good Morning America at 7am tomorrow, then you have the bankers group... David, are you listening? David's staring out the window. The sunlight has caught t building across the street just right to illuminate Richardson and McCrady on the second floor.

dialogues.text: I ' 11-keep you = posted, sir. Richardson hangs up the phone and turns .t look out at Da As he does he real zes David can see him.

dialogues.text: D` emit ! Richardson-steps back out of the sunlight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After you go back out there and talk to the New York channels--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, we need this on the nightly-- (catching up to David and

dialogues.text: David... Charlie looks at him for a moment, searching for the righ words to say to a friend...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
